newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam says tourist market set to double by 2000.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam says tourist market set to double by 2000.

text.p: Vietnam is set to become one of southeast Asia's leading tourist destinations, attracting more than three million visitors a year by the end of the century, the National Administration of Tourism predicted on Monday.

The tourism department's vice-chairman, Bui Xuan Nhat, told Reuters in an interview he expected 1.5 million foreign visitors -- about a quarter of them people on business -- to arrive in Vietnam this year, about 20 percent more than in 1995.
That would mark a slowdown from last year's growth of 35 percent and average annual growth of around 40 percent since Hanoi opened its doors to the outside world in the late 1980s.
Nhat shrugged off the slowdown in arrivals and said he was confident that the country's wealth of culture and natural attractions would keep tourists flowing in.
However, he said heavy investment was needed to improve the quality of services available for tourists and upgrade infrastructure.
"We have to raise the quality of service," he said. "The question of infrastructure is one of the biggest in developing countries. We can't solve that problem overnight."

The country is still a challenging destination for Western tourists because of poor roads, unreliable or sometimes non-existent public transport and a shortage of information. The most typical visitor is still the impecunious backpacker.
Nhat also said he was not overly concerned about a glut of hotel rooms which has emerged in Ho Chi Minh City and, to a lesser extent, in Hanoi.
He said the "invisible hand" of market forces would ensure that an equilibrium of supply and demand is eventually established.
The oversupply situation has hit state-run hotels, which generally offer poorer services than new foreign hotels, hard and left many with unsustainably low occupancy and room rates.
